The FEED contract involves Aker Solutions designing two DTUs for the Calliance and Brecknock fields and these will be configured as Tension Leg Platforms (TLPs). The DTUs gather well stream fluids from both subsea and dry-tree wells and then provide phase separation including free water knockout. The gas and condensate from the DTUs is then exported to the Central Processing Facility (CPF) in separate pipelines for further processing.

Installation of the trunkline will be conducted across two sections. First will be a nearshore section, including a 3km beach pull and up to 33km of pipelay to a water depth of up to 35 msw (114 fsw). Secondly, the offshore section - running from the end of the nearshore section to the Wheatstone platform sitting in 73 msw (239 fsw) - will cover an approximate length of 187km. The work scope includes the load out, transportation, construction, installation engineering, installation and pressure testing of the pipeline.

column8: Construction of 4 x Subsea Supply vessels
column16:
Maersk Supply Service has signed a deal with the Cosco Dalian shipyard in China for the construction of four new DP3 subsea supply vessels, of Marin Teknikk 6027 design, with options for two further units.
Delivery of the first vessels is scheduled for the fourth quarter of 2016. The newbuilds will be capable of working in up to 3,000 msw (9,840 fsw) and will be marketed towards international oil companies and construction companies. Main specifications of the vessels include a length of 137m (449ft), beam of 27m (89ft), deadweight of 8,000 tonnes, and a free deck capacity of 1,925 square metres. Additionally the vessels will be equipped with a 400-tonne AHC crane rated for 3,000 msw (9,840 fsw), a 3,000-tonne under-deck carousel, and accommodation for 120 persons in single cabins. They will also be prepared for a 275-tonne vertical lay tower over deck moon pool.

01/10: ONGC has awarded an EPCIC contract to NPCC for the RS-12 well platform project. Other scope in the EPCIC tender will include flowlines, cables and modifications. The scope of work includes survey, design and detailed engineering, procurement, fabrication, transportation, installation, hook-up, pre-commissioning and commissioning of the well platform.

10/09: Operator ONGC receives 6 bids for EPCIC contract covering RS12 WHP, flowlines, cables and modifications.

9/09: Bid closing date has extended to September 21, 2009. Afcon has asked Kencana to provide prices. WHP RS 14 will be removed from the work scope. It will include flowlines, cables and modifications.

02/10: Daewoo and HHI sign EPCIC contract. First steel at end 2010; jacket installation in Q4 2011 and deck,subsea installation and pipelay in end 2012. Deck installation likely to be subcontracted.

OMK will provide 35% of the pipes.

01/14: Contract to be signed in March.
6/13: the work scope covers one 900-km, 32-inch pipeline from Anapa to Varna. The deepest point is almost 2,200 msw. Also included in the scope are four steps of shore approach (for future pipes). There is also an option for the second pipeline.
EPC Lump Sum for 2 Annamaria platforms. Fabrication in Piomboni yard in Ravenna.

The Viktor Lenac yard will carry out 50% of work on platform construction.  Rosetti is taking care about design and supply of tagged items and Viktor Lenac's part is supply of steel and fabrication, as well as  piping, electrical and instrumentation installation.

05/13: The order consists of ten subsea production control umbilicals totaling approximately 84 kilometers (52.2 miles) in length and two electrical power cables totaling approximately 55 kilometers (34.2 miles) in length. Product manufacturing is planned to be performed at Oceaneering’s facility in Rosyth, Scotland and is expected to commence in the second quarter of 2013 and be completed in the third quarter 2014.

12/07: Burullus has awarded VetcoGray a USD 15 million contract to supply subsea and topside production control systems to a new gas field in the West Delta Deep Marine (WDDM) area offshore the Nile Delta.  The systems will be utilised on three wells in the Sequoia gas field. VetcoGray has already supplied similar equipment to other WDDM fields including Sinbad, Simian, Sienna and Sapphire. The Sequoia field will be linked into these systems, with installation due in 2009.

Awarded to KBR

Saipem has been awarded by Burullus Gas Company a contract for the development of the West Delta Deep Marine Phase IXa Project about 90 kilometres off the Mediterranean Coast of Egypt.
The scope of work encompasses engineering, procurement, installation, pre-commissioning and commissioning support of subsea facilities in the West Delta Deep Marine Concession, where Saipem already successfully performed earlier subsea development phases.
New facilities include rigid and flexible flowlines, umbilicals and other related subsea structures, to be installed in water depths up to 850 metres.
Marine activities will be carried out between the second and the fourth quarter of 2014.
Penspen providing basic engineering design to DESFA for the onshore pipeline, compressor stations, metering/regulation stations and SCADA/control system.
5/11: Saipem is understood to have won the tender.

2/13 BW has just signed a MOU with Pangea LNG BV to be the owner engineer of the King LNG FPSO project, which will serve the Tamar field off Israel. This includes the operations of the facility and potential ownership. DSME to likely still build unit and possibly take ownership stake
12/11: Under the agreement Hoegh will be the owner and operator of the LNG-FPSO and Daewoo will be the engineering, procurement, construction, installation and commissioning contractor.

3-year frame agreement, covering future developments in the Adriatic Sea, such as Bonaccia, Clara, Fauzia and Elettra. Covers all sorts of offshore construction and maintenance work, including the installation of platforms, pipelines and subsea structures, as well as diving and ROV support. The work will be carried out on a call-out basis with a fixed rate. A similar agreement has been signed with Micoperi.
Around 30% of contract is likely to be subcontracted.

3-year frame agreement, covering future developments in the Adriatic Sea, such as Bonaccia, Clara, Fauzia and Elettra. Covers all sorts of offshore construction and maintenance work, including the installation of platforms, pipelines and subsea structures, as well as diving and ROV support. The work will be carried out on a call-out basis with a fixed rate. A similar agreement has been signed with Saipem.

06/14: Diving support vessel Altus Optimus has been hired by RANA diving to conduct diving services during the installation of Eni’s Fauzia and Elettra platforms in the Italian northern Adriatic Sea.  
The vessel is currently en route from the Middle East to Italy in preparation for the expected 60-day charter, which is scheduled to begin in early July. Saipem has awarded RANA the saturation diving work for the tie-ins at the newly installed platforms. The scope of work involves metrology for closing tie-in spool fabrication, tie-in spool installation, riser and riser clamp installation, free-span corrections and assistance to pre-commissioning activities.

Van Oord expects to complete its contract in the fourth quarter of 2008.

The hull of the VARD 3 06 design vessel will be built at the Tulcea yard in Romania before being completed at Vard Langsten in Norway. Delivery is scheduled for mid-2016, Vard said in a statement without revealing the identity of the owner behind the order or the pricetag.
The vessel's hull is to be built at Vard's yard in Tulcea, Romania, while outfitting will be done at VARD Brattvaag in Norway with final delivery set for the second quarter of 2016.

EPIC contract for Saudi Aramco's Offshore Maintain Potential Program in Saudi Arabia. The contract, lasting seven years, is known as the Long Term Agreement (LTA), and consists of several packages that will be awarded in the coming years. The first package, comprising 13 jackets, 11 decks and one tie-in platform, requires J Ray to procure and construct over 17,500 tonnes of structures at its Jebel Ali facility in the UAE. These structures will be installed in water depths ranging from 14 to 55 metres. J Ray will deploy its own vessels to install 12 pipelines totaling 70km in length and six subsea cables totaling 53km as well as to carry out all work in the Zuluf, Safaniya, Marjan and Karan fields, offshore Saudi Arabia. Work on the first package is targeted for completion by 2009. J Ray says subsequent packages under the LTA will be confirmed on an annual basis as Saudi Aramco finalises their development plans and budget allocations.

08/08: Market sources indicate that ConocoPhillips has begun the tender process for a FEED contract for an accommodation platform on the Ekofisk field.  Though ConocoPhillips declined to comment, it is understood that three engineering contractors have been invited to participate. These are understood to be Aker Kvaerner with partner Leirvik Modules; Amec with Wood Group Engineering; and Bergen Group. It is believed that the Amec/Wood Group partnership plans to use Thailand's Vetco Aibel for fabrication if selected for the work, while Singapore-based SOME has been approached by another bidder but is likely to turn the offer down. It is believed that the platform would have a deck weight in excess of 10,000 tonnes.

12/07: StatoilHydro has awarded a NOK 1 billion EPC contract to Aker Kvaerner Subsea for a subsea production system to be utilised on the Morvin field in the Norwegian Sea.  Morvin will be developed as a 20km subsea tieback to the Aasgard B platform, with two four-slot manifolds, three horizontal subsea trees, a production control system, steel tube umbilicals, tie-in system and intervention tools. The production system to be used on the high pressure, high temperature field will be based on technology developed for the Kristin field development, and will be capable of handling pressures up to 15,000psi and temperatures up to 170 degrees Celsius. Contract documents are expected to be signed by Aker Kvaerner Subsea and StatoilHydro in December 2007, with final delivery of the production system due in May 2009. StatoilHydro intends to submit a PDO for Morvin in February 2008.

07/08: Aker Solutions has been awarded a NOK 50 million contract with StatoilHydro for work on its Norne M project.  The EPIC contract will include topside modifications for the tie-in of the M-template to the Norne FPSO. A new subsea template will be installed in the south sector of the Norne reservoir to increase production. The template will be connected both to the existing subsea infrastructure and to the Norne facility through a dedicated flowline and production riser. Aker Solutions' contract will cover execution of all topside modification work at the Norne FPSO to facilitate tie-in of the new production riser. Design and procurement work has started and fabrication work will begin in January 2009. Offshore installation will start early in 2009 with project completion and start-up due in November 2009. The Norne FPSO is one of the facilities included in the long term maintenance and modification contract with StatoilHydro in the Halten-Nordland area.

The workscope includes project management, assembly and installation of a production pipeline, a gas lift pipeline, a water injection pipeline and an oil export pipeline. In addition, Technip will also install a subsea structure, eight flexible risers, two umbilicals and will carry out pre-commissioning, tie-ins and testing. Technip's facility in Aberdeen will execute the contract, while offshore installation is scheduled for the third quarter of 2008 utilising the Apache and the Wellservicer. 10/08: The operator had earlier issued a letter of award and has also started pre-award contract negotiation with the HHI. The value of the contract is not disclosed, though market sources have placed it close to USD 1 billion. The CPP work scope covers the topside and the eight-legged jacket for the CPP (named PPS), which will weigh 17,000 tonnes and 5,000 tonnes respectively. The piles assembly for the jacket is estimated to weigh 4,000 tonnes. It is understood HHI will subcontract the fabrication of the jacket, while the topsides will be carried out in South Korea. The deck is scheduled for installation via a float-over method in 2011. Doris Engineering is HHI's partner for the contract. Detailed design of the platform will be done by Hyundai, with the topsides to be built at HHI's 229-acre offshore fabrication yard in Ulsan Port, South Korea. The jacket will be sub-contracted to a Chinese company, possibly Penglai Jutal Offshore Engineering. HHI is expected to deliver the PPS within 36 months.

12/12: Oceaneering has secured a contract from ExxonMobil to supply umbilicals for the Kizomba Satellites Phase 2 development located offshore Angola. 
The order is for electro-hydraulic steel tube control umbilicals totaling around 43km in length. Product manufacturing is planned to be performed at the Oceaneering Umbilical Solutions facility in Florida and is expected to commence in the third quarter of 2013 and be completed in the third quarter of 2014. The umbilicals will be used for the development of the Bavuca, Kakocha, and Mondo South fields in Block 15. The Bavuca and Kakocha umbilicals will tie back to the Kizomba B FPSO while the Mondo South umbilical will tie back to the Mondo FPSO.
